title: What contributed to the rise and fall of the civilization of the ancient Greeks? - Quora

response.answer_text: The rise of Hellenic Civilisation can really be attributed to three things: grapes, olives, and trade See, Greece isn't exactly prime real estate. It is very mountainous, has very poor soil, and has very hot summers. However, Greece was blessed with being able to grow abundant olives and grapes, and having natural harbours. In the ancient world, olives and grapes were very important commodities. Olive oil became very important in culinary arts, and grapes can be used to make wine. With these two trade goods, many Greek states became commercial powers. Honestly, when we talk about Ancient Greece, we're talking about Athens. It was after all Athens that developed democracy, the Parthenon, the philosophy of Socrates, the writings of Plato and Aristotle, et cetera. With the grape and the olive, Athens made enough money to import grain from Asia Minor. It established colonies across the Mediterranean. It, along with Sparta, defeated the seemingly unbeatable Persian Empire.  Yet Athens was never able to establish true hegemony over the other Greeks. The Peloponnesian War ended in disaster for Athens and left Sparta in control, but Sparta didn't have the population or money to maintain control over the Greeks. The failure of Sparta to achieve hegemony allowed the Macedonians, under Phillip II, to conqueror almost all of Greece. His son Alexander would then defeat the Persians and spread Greek culture over much of the known world. Yet Alexander's death without a suitable heir naturally meant his empire would collapse, and within a generation the Greeks were again split. This of course allowed the Romans to muscle in. However, although the Greeks were militarily defeated by the Romans, Greek culture largely conquered Rome and survived even the fall of the Western Roman Empire, surviving the Eastern (Byzantine) Empire where Greek remained the dominant language.
